{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = Len Keys | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Leonard John Keys | birth_date = {{Birth date|1880|08|03|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Patea]], New Zealand | death_date = {{Death date and age|1958|01|26|1880|08|03|df=y}} | death_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | spouse = {{marriage|Sarah Margery McMaster|1903}} | occupation = Grocer
Bus operator | country = New Zealand | sport = [[Bowls|Lawn bowls]] | club = Auckland Bowling Club | nationals = Fours champion (1932) }} '''Leonard John Keys''' (3 August 1880 – 1958) was a New Zealand [[bowls|lawn bowls]] player who competed for his country at the [[New Zealand at the 1934 British Empire Games|1934 British Empire Games]]. However, he is more notable as a businessman and one of the pioneers of passenger bus services in [[Auckland]]. ==Early life and family== Born in [[Patea]] on 3 August 1880, Keys was the son of Harriet Jane Keys (née Watson) and John Edward Keys.{{cite book |title=Who's Who N.Z. |year=1938 |publisher=National Magazines |location=Wellington |page=273}} He grew up in the [[Thames, New Zealand|Thames]] area, before serving an apprenticeship as a grocer in Auckland.{{cite web |url=https://www.remuera.org.nz/about-us/history-and-heritage/13-about-us/heritage-walk/183-lj-keys-and-the-clonbern-store |title=LJ Keys and the Clonbern store |year=2014 |publisher=Remuera Business Association |accessdate=16 June 2018}} In 1903, he married Sarah Margery McMaster, and the couple went on to have three children. ==Lawn bowls== Keys was a member of the Auckland Bowling Club team that won the men's fours title at the 1932 national lawn bowls championships, held in [[Christchurch]].{{cite book |editor-last=McLintock |editor-first=A.H. |editorlink=Alexander Hare McLintock |chapter=Bowls, men's outdoor—tournament winners |title=An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/1966/bowls-mens-outdoor/page-5 |accessdate=16 June 2018 |year=1966 |publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage}} He went on to represent New Zealand in the men's singles at the [[Lawn Bowls at the 1934 British Empire Games|1934 British Empire Games]] in [[London]].{{cite news | url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19340925.2.26 | title=Empire bowlers: success of England | date=25 September 1934 | work=New Zealand Herald | accessdate=16 June 2018 | page=6}} He lost all nine of his round-robin matches, finishing in tenth, and last, place. ==Business activities== Keys ran a grocery business in the Auckland suburb of [[Remuera]], on the corner of Remuera and Clonbern Roads, between 1907 and 1914.{{cite web |url=http://www.remueraheritage.org.nz/places/l-j-keys |title=L J Keys |date=7 March 2016 |website=Remuera Heritage |accessdate=16 June 2018}} The following year, he established a passenger bus service running between Remuera and [[Saint Heliers]], and in 1923 began a service with three buses from Saint Heliers into central Auckland. In 1925, ferry services from Saint Heliers to the city ceased operation, and Keys expanded his bus service on the route. By 1949, when his business was taken over by the Auckland Transport Board, Keys had a fleet of about 40 buses. Keys served as a member of the Tamaki West Road Board for nine years, and was a member of the [[Auckland Chamber of Commerce]] and the Omnibus Proprietors' Association. ==Death== Keys died on 26 January 1958, and his ashes were buried at Purewa Cemetery.{{cite web |url=http://www.purewa.co.nz/view/?id=24948 |title=Burial & cremation details: Leonard John Keys |publisher=Purewa Cemetery and Crematorium |accessdate=16 June 2018}} His wife, Margery, died in 1969.{{cite web |url=http://www.purewa.co.nz/view/?id=17353 |title=Burial & cremation details: Sarah Margery Keys |publisher=Purewa Cemetery and Crematorium |accessdate=16 June 2018}} ==Honorific eponym== Keys Terrace in the Auckland suburb of Saint Heliers is named in Keys' honour. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{1934 New Zealand British Empire Games team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Keys, Len}} [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1958 deaths]] [[Category:People from Patea]] [[Category:New Zealand male bowls players]] [[Category:Bowls players at the 1934 British Empire Games]] [[Category:Local political office-holders in New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Burials at Purewa Cemetery]]

'''Managerial hubris''' is the unrealistic belief held by managers in bidding firms that they can manage the assets of a target firm more efficiently than the target firm's current management. Managerial hubris is one reason a manager may choose to invest in a [[merger]] that on average generates no [[profit (economics)|profit]]s.<ref>{{cite book|title=Strategic Management and Competitive Advantages|author=Jay B. Barney and William S. Hesterly|pages=380|publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall|date=2008|isbn=0-13-613520-X}}</ref>

The '''Michelin Cup''' refers to a number of competitions sponsored by the French tyre manufacturer [[Michelin]] for long distance flight made in [[aeroplane]]s. [[File:Coupemichelin.jpg|thumb|]] The first Michelin prize was announced in March 1908. The principal prize, to be awarded annually for an initial period of eight years, was a prize for long distance flight, and consisted of a bronze statue as a trophy (valued at 10,000 FF-[[French francs]]) and a money prize of 20,000 FF. The flying club of the winner also received a replica of the trophy if they did not already own one. Administration and determination of the exact conditions for each year were delegated to the [[Aéro-Club de France]] (AeCF). Attempts to win the prize could be made anywhere in the world where there was a flying club associated with the AeCF.
At the same time, '''Prix d'Aviation Michelin''' was a special prize of 100,000 francs offered for a flight by an aircraft carrying a passenger, taking off from either the department of [[Seine]] or [[Seine-et-Oise]], flying over the [[Arc de Triomphe]] and the cathedral of [[Clermont-Ferrand]], and landing on the summit of the {{convert|1456|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Puy de Dôme]] inside six hours starting from the time at the Arc de Triomphe.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6550620m/f125.image.r=Michelin.langEN|page=115|language=French|date=March 1908|title=La Coupe d'Aviation et les Prix d'Aviation Michelin}}</ref> This was won by [[Eugène Renaux]] on 7 March 1911, flying a [[Farman MF.7|Maurice Farman biplane]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200205.html|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|date=11 March 1911|title =Renaux wins the Michelin Puy de Dome Prize|page=207}}</ref>
In 1909, a second award, the '''British Empire Michelin Cup''', was announced, for flights made by aviators who were citizens of the British Empire, flying aircraft of all-British manufacture. The original award therefore became known as the '''International Michelin Cup'''.
When the prizes were first instituted, 25 [[French franc]]s were worth one [[pound Sterling]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200181.html|title=Prize Treatise on Aerial Navigation|date=27 March 1909|page=183}}</ref>
==International Michelin Cup==
===1908=== Won by [[Wilbur Wright]] with a flight made on 31 December 1908 at [[Le Mans]] officially reckoned as {{convert|124.7|km|mi|abbr=on}}. The course over which the flight was made was an isosceles triangle with two sides of 1 km and a third of 200 m, totalling 2.2 km. The flight had to be made before sunset and only complete circuits counted. Wright took off at 2 pm and completed 56 circuits before sunset. He then landed, flying a further 1.5 km to set a new world distance record of 124.7 km.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200022.html|date=9 Jan 1924|title=Wright's Final Effort for the 1908 Michelin Prize. |page=24}}</ref>
===1909=== For the greatest distance exceeding 123.2 km. in a closed circuit made before the end of the year: 20,000 francs, and a bronze replica of the Michelin trophy.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=Michelin Cup Rules for 1909 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200050.html|date=23 January 1909|page= 52}}</ref>
Won by [[Henry Farman]] with a flight of {{convert|234.212|km|mi|abbr=on}} lasting 4h 6m 25s made on 3 November 1909 at [[Châlons-en-Champagne|Chalons]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65523525/f13.image.|title=Pour la Coupe Michelin|date=1 January 1911|page=7|language=French}}</ref>
===1910=== Won by [[Maurice Tabuteau]] flying a [[Farman MF.7|Maurice Farman biplane]] with a flight of {{convert|584.745|km|mi|abbr=on}}, taking 7hr 48m 36.6s at Buc on 30 December 1910.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65523525/f32.image.n|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=1 January 1911|page=26|language=French}}</ref>
===1911=== In 1911, the closing date for the competition was brought forward to 31 October.
Won by E. Helen flying a [[Nieuport II]] monoplane on 8 September 1911, when he covered {{convert|1,252.8|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 14 hr 7 min.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200964.html|title=Helen wins Michelin Cup|date=4 November 1911|page=966}}</ref>
===1912=== For the 1912 competition, the rules were considerably elaborated. The flight had to be made over a course made up of three different circuits, each starting from the same point. The first and third, each of about {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}}, had to have three or four compulsory landing-places, and the second, of {{convert|255|km|mi|abbr=on}}, one or two landing places. Refuelling was only allowed at the starting point of each circuit. The circuits had to be covered in order, and if a competitor landed somewhere other than a nominated airfield, they had to start that circuit again. For every 75 kg of useful load carried apart from the pilot and necessary fuel, a bonus of 25% was allowed on the time, up to a maximum of 100 per cent. The extra load could be made up of passengers or ballast. Competing aircraft had to carry a sealed [[barograph]], and an average speed of at least {{convert|40|kph|mph|abbr=on}} had to be maintained.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200179.html|title=1912 International Michelin Competition|date=24 February 1912|page=179 }}</ref>
The 1912 prize was not won by any competitor, and the prize money was added to the prize for the following year.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6552332d/f386.image.r=coupe%20michelin378|date=15 August 1913|title=Pour La Coupe Michelin}}</ref>
===1913=== The 1913 competition was very different. It was awarded for the greatest distance flown on a series of consecutive days, flying over a {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} course, with a compulsory landing after each circuit.
The Cup was won by Emmanuel Helen flying a Nieuport monoplane, with a total distance of {{convert|16096.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} flown between 22 October and 29 November 1913.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=Helen's Record for the Michelin Cup|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%201305.html|page=1331|date=6 December 1913}}</ref>
===1914=== The nature of the competition was changed again for the 1914 competition, the prize being awarded for the fastest time over a circuit of about {{convert|3000|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Won by [[Eugène Gilbert]] flying a Morane-Saulnier monoplane. Starting from [[Villacoublay]] at 03:04 on 8 June 1914, he flew via [[Péronne, Somme|Peronne]], [[Rheims]], [[Saint-Dizier]], [[Gray, Haute-Saône|Gray]], [[Joigny]], [[Beaune]], [[Vienne]] and [[Nimes]], landing at [[Mirande]] before reaching [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]], owing to running out of fuel. On the next day he flew via Pau, [[Saint-André-de-Cubzac|St. André de Cubzac]], [[Romorantin]], [[Angers]], [[Evreux]] and [[Calais]] back to Villacoublay, landing at 18:37 p.m, having covered a distance of {{convert|2970|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 39h 35m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1914/1914%20-%200636.html|title=Gilbert Flies Round France in Two Days|date=June 12, 1914|page=636}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6585089x/f29.image|title=Performances de la Quinzaine|page=301|date= 1 July 1914}}</ref>
===1921=== After the [[First World War]], the competition was resumed in 1921. The competition was for the fastest time over a (3,000 km {1,860 mi) circuit: the French circuit was [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]—[[Amiens]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand]]—[[Saint-Dizier]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Joigny]]—[[Beaune]]—[[Lyon]]—[[Nîmes]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]–[[Romorantin]],—[[Angers]]—[[Évreux]]—[[Calais]]—Versailles, and the aircraft had to land at each of these airfields.
The result was the cause of considerable controversy. The best French time was achieved by [[Alphonse Poiré]] flying a [[Caudron C.60]], who completed the circuit in 37h 23m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200608.html|title= The International Michelin Cup|date=8 September 1921|page= 608}}</ref> A faster time of 35h 45m over an Italian circuit was achieved by Capt Raffaele Martinetti-Bianchi<ref>L'Aéreophile 1-15 octobre 1921</ref>,<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200859.html|date= 29 December 1921|page=859|title=The Michelin Cup}}</ref> but he had not landed at the same aerodrome as he had departed from, since this had become waterlogged and he was not allowed to land there. The dispute between the Italian authorities, who had ratified his performance, and the Aéro-Club de France was taken to a specially appointed [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] committee, which found in Martinetti's favour, but the AeCF disputed their judgement: eventually the prize was held to have been won by neither man, although in recognition of his performance the AeCF awarded the Gold Medal of the AeCF and a sum of money equal to the Michelin Prize to Poiré.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6555017m/f162.image.r=Martinetti|title=Comité de Direction|date=1 May 1923|page=156}}</ref>
===1922-3=== A five-year extension, with annual prizes of 20,000 francs, was announced in 1922. The time period of the annual competition was altered to run from the beginning of July in one year to the end of the following June.
Won by Capt Girier flying a [[Breguet 14]], taking 20hr 41m 57sec, covering the course [[Lyons]]—[[Nimes]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Angers]]—[[Saint-Inglevert|St. Inglevert]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand|Mourmelon]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Avord]]—Lyons at an average speed (including time on the ground) of {{convert|136.2|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6555017m/f213.image|page=201|date=1 July 1923|title= La Coupe Michelin}}</ref>
===1923-4=== The 1924 French circuit was [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]—[[Saint-Inglevert]]—[[Valenciennes]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand|Mourmelon]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyon]]—[[Nimes]]—[[Toulouse]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Angers]]—Versailles
Won by Lieut. [[Ludovic Arrachart]] flying a [[Breguet 19]], completing the {{convert|2935|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 19h 22m 26s.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]] 1924 ''Salon Aéronautique'' issue |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6554816n/f429.image|title=Les Moteurs d'Aviation Renault|page=31 }}</ref>
===1924-5=== Won by [[Pelletier d'Oisy]] flying a [[Blériot-SPAD S.61]], completing the course in 15h 8m.<ref name=Raids>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553816b/f203.image|title=Raids, Records et Performances|page=197|date=1 July 1925}}</ref>
===1925-6=== At the request of the military aviation authorities, the 1925-6 competition was limited to competitors flying the principal French bombing aircraft, the [[Breguet 19]].<ref name=Raids/> The best time was achieved by Capt. Coslin, with Lieut Gérard as observer, with a time of 18h 0m 24s, a speed of {{convert|163.6|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547488/f205.image|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=1 July 1926| page=199}}</ref>
However, since this time did not better the previous best, the cup did not change hands.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553815x/f242.image|title=Les Coupe Michelin | date=1 August 1927 |page=236 }}</ref>
===1926-7=== There were two competitions in 1926-7, one restricted to the Breguet 19. The course for both competitions was Paris ([[Paris–Le Bourget Airport|Le Bourget]])—[[Nancy, France|Nancy]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Bourges]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyons]]—[[Istres]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Cazaux Air Base|Casaux]]—[[Châteauroux]]—[[Tours]]—[[Romorantin-Lanthenay|Romorantin]]—[[Chartres]]—Paris, a distance of {{convert|2727.5|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547488/f165.image|date= 1 May 1926|title=Nouvell Coupe Michelin|page=159|language=French}}</ref>
The main competition was won by Capitain Challes flying a [[Blériot-SPAD S.61]] in 12h 14m 37s.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1927/1927%20-%200470.html|title=The Michelin Cup|date= 30 June 1927|page= 428}}</ref>
The military competition was won by Capt Delaître and Sgt Cailloge, who covered the course in 14h 51m 55s, a speed of {{convert|187.95|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65538437/f30.image|title=Réception des Lauréats des Militaries|date=1 February 1928|page= 62}}</ref>
===1927-8=== Again, the competition was restricted to the Breguet 19, with the added condition that an altitude of {{convert|4000|m|ft|abbr=on}} be reached at least once.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553846g/f27.image.r=coupe%20michelin|title=Les Militaries 1928|date=1 May 1928|page=155}}</ref>
Won by Capt. Delaître.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]] |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553851s/f29.image|title=Commission Sportive|date= 1 October 1928|page=317}}</ref>
===1928-9=== In 1928, the prize was offered for a further four years. The winning flight had to be made in France, although the competition was open to all nationalities, and the competition was restricted to single-seater aircraft with an engine of 230 hp or less. A minimum average speed of {{convert|185|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} had to be maintained over the circuit, including time spent on the ground at the fifteen cities making up the circuit.<ref name=F32_623>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200671.html|date= 8 July 1932|page=623 |title=The Michelin Cup}}</ref> Won by [[Michel Détroyat]], flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.230]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1930/untitled0%20-%200683.html|date= 20 June 1920|page= 651|title=Vincennes}}</ref>
===1929-30=== Won by [[Michel Détroyat]], flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.130]], completing the {{convert|2788|km|mi|abbr=on}} course [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport|Paris (Le Bourget)]]—[[Reims]]—[[Nancy, France|Nancy]]— [[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyons]]—[[Montpellier]]— [[Perpignan]]—[[Toulouse]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Tours]]—Le Bourget at an average speed of {{convert|190.2|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6554360b/f216.image.|title=L'Aviation Français|date=1 July 1930|page=210 }}</ref>
===1930-31=== Won by [[Marcel Haegelen]] flying the Lorraine-Hanriot LH.41, with a time of 11h 37m 21s, an average speed of {{convert|226.45|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553565s/f12.image|title=Coupe Michelin|date=15 July 1931|page=204}}</ref>
===1931-2=== Won by [[Marcel Haegelen]] flying the Lorraine-Hanriot LH 41, completing the {{convert|2631|km|mi|abbr=on}} course at an average speed of {{convert|254|kph|mph|abbr=on}} on 23 June 1932.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65536654/f30.image|title=Commission Sportive| date=August 1932 |page=254 }}</ref>
===1932–3=== Won by Michel Détroyat flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.230#Variants|Moraine Saulnier MS.234]], completing the {{convert| 2902|km|mi|abbr=on}} course at an average speed of {{convert|222.537|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65535577/f8.image|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=November 1933|page=328 }}</ref>
===1934===
===1935=== Won by Maurice Arnoux flying a [[Caudron C.430|Caudron C.430/1]], completing the {{convert|2902|km|mi|abbr=on}} course in 10h 7m, a speed of {{convert|286.85|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547614/f41.image|title= La Coupe Michelin|date= November 1935|page=341}}</ref>
==British Michelin cup== In 1909, Michelin instituted a United Kingdom award, offering an annual award for five years of a trophy and £500. The competition was limited to British subjects flying aircraft of British construction. Administration of the competition was entrusted to the [[Royal Aero Club|Aero Club of Great Britain]]. <ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200185.html|date= 27 March 1909 |page=187|title=A British Michelin Cup }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]| url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200758.html|date=17 September 1910|page=756|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup }}</ref>
===1909–10=== For the first year, the flight was to be around a closed circuit made up of two or more markers, and a minimum distance of {{convert|5|mi|km}} was specified. The closing date for the first competition was 31 March 1910.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200189.html|page= 185|date=8 March 1910|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup}}</ref>
Won by [[John Moore-Brabazon, 1st Baron Brabazon of Tara|J. T. C. Moore-Brabazon]] with a flight of {{convert|18.75|mi|km|abbr=on}} at [[RNAS Eastchurch|Eastchurch]] on 1 March 1910, flying the [[Short Biplane No. 2]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=British Michelin Trophy Winner|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200279.html|page=277|date =9 April 1910}}</ref>
===1910=== The rules for the 1910 competition, for which the closing date was 31 December 1910, were as before except that the minimum qualifying distance was raised to {{convert|38|mi|km|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200758.html|date= 17 September 1910|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup}}</ref>
Won by [[Samuel Franklin Cody|Samuel Cody]] flying the [[Cody Michelin Cup Biplane]] at Laffan's Plain, Farnborough with a flight of {{convert|185.46|mi|km|abbr=on}} taking 4h 47m.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200007.html|date=7 January 1911|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=The British Michelin Cup| page=7 }}</ref>
===1911=== Announcement of a second prize, to be competed for during the following three years, with a trophy and a cash prize of £400 for 1911, £600 for 1912 and £800 for 1913, for the fastest time over a cross-country circuit.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200292.html|date= April 1911|title=British Empire Michelin Cup No.2|page=294}}</ref>
On 29 October 1911, the Michelin Cup No. 1 was again won by Samuel Cody, flying his [[Cody Circuit of Britain biplane|Circuit of Britain biplane]] {{convert|261.5|mi|km}} in 5 hr 15 min at Laffan's Plain, also setting a new British duration record.<ref name= FL1911/>
The No. 2 cup was also won by Cody, with a flight made on 11 September 1911 of a circuit starting at Laffan's Plain, [[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]]—[[Andover, Hampshire|Andover]]—[[Hendon Aerodrome|Hendon]]—[[Brooklands]]—Farnborough, taking 3 hr 6 min 30 sec to complete the {{convert|125|mi|km}} course.<ref name= FL1911>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200980.html|title=Official Notices |date=11 November 1911 |page=982 }}</ref>
===1912=== The rules were redefined for the 1912 competition: the No. 1 cup and cash prize of £5,000 was purely for endurance, all flying to be done between sunrise and sunset. The No. 2 cup and prize of £600 was for distance covered over a cross-country course of about {{convert|186|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the competitor's choosing.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200468.html|date=25 May 1912 |title=Notices to Members |page= }}</ref>
The No. 1 cup was won by [[Harry Hawker]] flying the [[Sopwith-Wright biplane]], with a flight lasting 8 hours 23 minutes made on 24 October 1912 at [[Brooklands]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%201005.html|date=2 November 1912|title=British Duration Records|page=1005}}</ref>
The No. 2 cup was won by Samuel Cody flying the [[Cody V]], with a flight of 186 miles in 3hr 26m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200946.html|title= Col. Cody Again Wins Michelin Cup No. 2. |date=19 October 1912 |page=946 }}</ref>
===1913=== Michelin Cup No. 1 for the longest distance flight round the course Brooklands–Hendon–[[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]], with a minimum distance of 300 miles. Competitors had to make periodical stops of not less than five minutes, with engine stopped, on completing an entire circuit of the course plus one section: e.g., starting from Brooklands the competitor would pass Hendon, Farnborough, Brooklands, and alight at Hendon.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup No. 1|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200404.html|date= 12 April 1913|page= 412}}</ref> The prize had not been won by the closing date of 31 October 1913, so the closing date was extended to 14 November 1913.
The No. 1 Cup was won by [[Reginald H. Carr]] flying the [[Grahame-White Type X|Grahame White "Charabanc"]], with a flight of over {{convert|300|mi|km|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title= Reginald H. Carr|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%201238.html|date= 22 November 1913|page= 1261}}</ref>
The No. 2 cup, for the fastest time round a circuit of the competitor's choice of about 450 km, was not awarded. Although the prize was carried over to the next year, competition was terminated by the outbreak of [[World War I]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1914/1914%20-%200342.html|title=Notices to members|date=28 March 1914|page=342}}</ref>

[[Image:PostcardTurpentineWorkers1912.jpg|thumb|right|250px|1912 postcard]] The '''naval stores industry''' collects, processes, and markets [[forest product]]s refined from the [[oleoresin]] of the [[slash pine]] and [[longleaf pine]] trees (genus ''Pinus''). The industry was associated with the maintenance of the [[wooden ship]]s and sailing tackle of pre-20th century navies, which were [[caulk]]ed and [[waterproof]]ed using the pitch (or resin, also known as [[pine tar|tar]]) of the pine tree.<ref>Earley, p. 87</ref>
==History== [[File:CupGutterSystem.jpg|thumb|[[Charles Herty|Herty system]] in use on turpentine trees in northern Florida, circa 1936]] [[File:Herty turpentine cup.jpg|thumb|Herty turpentine cup, made of clay. The hole is for nailing to a pine tree.]] [[File:Turpentine cup.jpg|thumb|Turpentine cup made of tin, was attached to a pine tree.]]
With the demise of wooden ships, those uses of pine resin ended, but the industry remained vigorous as new products created new markets. First extensively described by [[Frederick Law Olmsted]] in his book ''A Journey in the Seaboard Slave States'' (1856),<ref>Olmsted, Ch. 5, pp. 110-173</ref> the naval stores industry was one of the economic mainstays of the southeastern [[United States]] until the late 20th century. Despite a rapid decline of the gum naval stores industry in the last quarter of the 20th century, a few places in the southeastern United States still rely on it as a major part of their livelihood.<ref>Outland, p. 5</ref>
'''Gum naval stores cultivation''' refers to the labor-intensive method of extracting pine resin from the trees (the raw gum). The method of collection—tapping the trees—vaguely resembles that used on a rubber plantation or in a maple sugar grove. However, instead of preparing the tree to receive a pipe or tap, the tree is gashed with an inch-wide curved blade, called a "hack," to remove all of the bark down through the cambium layer. An angled piece of galvanized tin is then placed below the eight-inch-long, one-inch-wide gash (also known as "the streak") to direct the oozing [[Sap (plant)|sap]] into a quart-sized rectangular cup fixed to the tree. Each new "streak" is put onto the tree above the preceding one, and gradually a vertical "cat face" more than thirty inches in height is formed. Through the mid-twentieth century, a "puller," a type of hack that had a long handle, was used to extend the streak up the tree to a height of more than seven feet.
Once, large operators, known as "factors," controlled huge tracts of forests, some in the hundreds of thousands of acres, which they leased to "operators," and also advanced them capital, usually in the form of tools and other equipment and goods with which to operate. The operators satisfied their debt to the factors by returning the produce, barrels of resin. The name "Factors Walk" on the riverfront in [[Savannah, Georgia]], commemorates an area on the Savannah River harbor where thousands of barrels of produce were collected for [[transshipment]]. Between 1880 and 1920, Savannah was the largest port for naval stores products and continued to set the world price of naval stores until 1950.<ref>Outland, pp. 56-57; 147-150; 295</ref><ref>Earley, pp. 136-137</ref>
==Basic processes==
The basic raw material, [[pine resin]], once collected, is converted into two major products — [[rosin]] and [[turpentine]]. For many years rosin and turpentine were used unprocessed in common household products such as soap, paper, paint, and [[varnish]]. Today most rosin is altered to be used in a wide range of products that includes paper sizing, surface coatings, adhesives, printing inks, and rubber compounds. Turpentine, like rosin, has become a versatile material exploited to develop uses in fragrances, flavors, vitamins, household cleaning products, medicines, and [[polyterpene resin]].
==Industry today==
Because of a shortage of workers willing to perform the heavy manual labor involved in the streaking of many acres of trees and in collecting the resin tree by tree as well, the gum naval stores industry entered a period of steep decline beginning in the 1960s. As of 2001, only one large-scale facility (begun as [[Filtered Rosin Products]]) in [[Baxley, Georgia]], continued in operation, serving the remaining naval stores producers in the surrounding area. Gradually, the method of tapping trees to obtain naval stores products has become overshadowed by industries which yield these products as [[byproduct]]s of other operations.<ref>Outland, pp. 300-307</ref>

[[File:Drøbak kirke 1.jpg|thumb|Drøbak Church built in 1776]] [[File:Drobak, Norway (14863290074).jpg|thumb| Drøbak Hospital built in 1793]] '''Niels Carlsen''' (8 January 1734 – 3 May 1809) was a Norwegian timber merchant, landowner, shipowner and banker. Carlsen was one of the biggest ship owners in Norway of his time. <ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Niels Carlsen |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Bernhard |last=Magnussen |authorlink= |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Niels_Carlsen/utdypning |language=Norwegian |accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref>
==Career== Carlsen was born in [[Drøbak]] in [[Akershus]], Norway. He was the son of Jacob Carlsen (ca. 1685-1749) and Maria Jørgensdatter Frost. His father had married the widow of his employer and took over the trading business. Drøbak had a favorable location situated on east side of [[Drøbak Sound]], at the narrowest part of the [[Oslo Fjord]]. It was near the capital, had good anchoring and mooring facilities and a protective harbor. <ref>{{cite web|url= https://snl.no/Dr%C3%B8bak|title=Drøbak|publisher= Store norske leksikon|author= Svein Askheim|accessdate= July 15, 2016}}</ref>
Niels Carlsen and his half brothers Christian went into their father's business and expanded it. The brothers were shipowners, forest owners, traded in both imports and exports and took part in the financing operations that came with the profession. Carlsen bought up forest lands on both sides of the bay, floated the logs into circulation plots which he had acquired along Drøbak Sound, operated a sawmill and built bulwark against the sea to facilitate the loading of ships. He owned a large part of the property along the seafront as well as the small islands where [[Oscarsborg Fortress]] is now situated. With these acquisition, he initiated the operation of a ferry landing, plus guest house and coaching inn.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Niels Carlsen |first= |last= |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |editor-last=Godal | editor-first=Anne Marit | editor-link=Anne Marit Godal |publisher=Norsk nettleksikon |location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/Niels_Carlsen |language=Norwegian|accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref>
Carlsen married Martha Zachariassen (1743–1821), the daughter of Zacharias Simonsen Wesseltoft (1701-1777), a wealthy merchant and shipowner in [[Skien]]. She and her family contributed to the further development of Carlsen's business and to the development of Drøbak. Carlsen and his wife donated funds for a wooden cruciform church, hospital and school. Drøbak Church (''Drøbak kirke'') was fully furnished and was inaugurated in 1776. Facing the church is the building which was dedicated as a hospital and hostel for poor widows in 1793. A bust of Carlsen, made by [[Arne Vinje Gunnerud]], is located between Drøbak Church and the old Drøbak Hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.frogn.kirken.no/kirkene/drobak-kirke|title=Drøbak kirke|publisher= kirken i Drobak og Frogn|author= Leif Lund-Berg|date= 17 July 1996|accessdate= July 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://verneforeningen.no/international-visitors/history-of-drobak/|title= History of Drøbak|publisher = verneforeningen.no |accessdate= July 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://verneforeningen.no/walks-around-drobak/ |title= Walks in and around Drøbak|publisher= verneforeningen.no |accessdate= July 15, 2016}}</ref>

'''Oleksandr Vyacheslavovych Slobodian''' ({{lang-uk|Олександр В'ячеславович Слободян}}: born February 21, 1956 in [[Ternopil]], [[Ukraine]]<ref name=RBCU/>) is a [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] millionaire [[businessman]] and [[politician]]. He is the original CEO and current honorary president of the [[Kiev]]-based [[Obolon CJSC]], Europe's largest [[brewing]] company, and the president of the [[Ukrainian Premier League]] [[football club]] [[Obolon Kyiv]] (both since 1998).<ref name=DELLO>{{uk icon}} [http://delo.ua/wiki/slobodjan-aleksandr-110818/ Dossier], [[DELO]]</ref>
==Biography== Slobodian graduated from the [[Kiev Technological Institute of Food Science]] in 1978.<ref name=DELLO/> Since 1980 he works for [[Obolon CJSC]].<ref name=DELLO/> In 1989, he became CEO and in 1993 the head of the board of Obolon.<ref name=DELLO/> In 1998, he landed th posts President of CJSC Obolon and President of [[FC Obolon Kyiv]].<ref name=DELLO/>
Slobodian was also a long-time [[member of parliament]] in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (from [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1998|1998]] till December 2012), representing the [[Our Ukraine (pre 2007)|Our Ukraine Bloc]] & [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]] as a member of [[Ukrainian People's Party]] from [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2002|2002]] till December 2012.<ref name=RBCU>{{uk icon}} [http://www.rbc.ua/ukr/vyboru2012/person/m3036 Слободян Олександр В’ячеславович], [[RBC Ukraine]]</ref><ref>[http://gska2.rada.gov.ua/pls/site/p_exdeputat?d_id=2256&skl=5 Profile on Verkhovna Rada website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327040258/http://gska2.rada.gov.ua/pls/site/p_exdeputat?d_id=2256&skl=5 |date=2008-03-27 }}</ref> Slobodian is a member of the Ukrainian People's Party since 1997.<ref name=RBCU/> Since 1999 he is deputy head of the party.<ref name=RBCU/> In [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|the 2012 parliamentary election]] Slobodian unsuccessfully tried to get (re)-elected into parliament by falling to win a [[single-member districts]] (number 187) ([[first-past-the-post]] wins a parliament seat) located in [[Khmelnytskyi, Ukraine|Khmelnytskyi]] as an [[Independent (politician)|independent candidate]].<ref name="KPresultsUKPE201291112">[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/results-of-the-vote-count-continuously-updated-315153.html Results of the vote count], [[Kyiv Post]] (9 November 2012)</ref><ref name=Cherno>{{uk icon}} [http://www.chesno.org/meter/person/114/ Слободян Олександр В'ячеславович], [[Civil movement "Chesno"]]</ref> He was runner-up in the district with 28.26% of the votes.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.rbc.ua/ukr/vyboru2012/person/o25 Одномандатный избирательный округ № 187], [[RBC Ukraine]]</ref>
On 21 February 2013 [[FC Obolon Kyiv]] (which he was the president of) withdrew voluntarily from the Ukrainian First League after Slobodyan had refused to finance the club after goalkeeper [[Kostyantyn Makhnovskyi]] was sold by the club without his consent.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://news.liga.net/news/sport/764405-slobodyan_otkazalsya_finansirovat_fk_obolon.htm Slobodyan refused to fund FC "Obolon"], www.liga.net (9 December 2012)</ref><ref name=OKFCnomore>{{uk icon}} [http://news.liga.net/ua/news/sport/815911-obolon_of_ts_yno_znyalasya_z_chemp_onatu_ukra_ni.htm "Obolon" refused to brew in the spring part in the First League, but instead in Kiev there will be a new club], www.liga.net (21 February 2013)</ref> In December 2012 Slobodian announced he would create a new team under the moniker "[[Obolon Brovar]]".<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://news.liga.net/news/sport/779411-slobodyan_sozdaet_novyy_futbolnyy_klub_obolon_brovar.htm Slobodyan creates new Football club "Obolon Brovar"], www.liga.net (11 December 2012)</ref>
Slobodian did not participate in the [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]].<ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2014/WP401E?pt001f01=910&lit=76&current_row=31 Alphabetical Index of candidates in 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election], [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]</ref>

{{for|the role of registered agent in the US|Registered Agent}}
A '''process agent''' is a [[agent (law)|representative]] upon whom [[court]] papers may be served. In the US, the role is generally a requirement of US State law and is known as a [[registered agent]], a resident agent or statutory agent. However, process agents are utilized in the US by [[truck drivers]], [[brokers]] or [[freight forwarders]]<ref>https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/registration/process-agents</ref> for similar purposes. Process agents that provide nationwide coverage for motor carriers are commonly referred to as blanket companies<ref>http://li-public.fmcsa.dot.gov/LIVIEW/pkg_html.prc_limain</ref>.
In the UK, a process agent is a contractual relationship, permitted by the Civil Procedure Rules.
==England and Wales==
Under English Civil Procedure Rules,<ref>[http://www.justice.gov.uk/courts/procedure-rules/civil Civil Procedure Rules]</ref> it is necessary to serve papers to start proceedings correctly.<ref>Civil Procedure Rules, Part 6</ref> If a party does not have an address within the United Kingdom, the procedure for serving these papers can be lengthy and complicated, with proof of service particularly difficult in some circumstances.<ref>Civil Procedure Rules, Practice Direction 6A</ref>
It is therefore customary to appoint a process agent and contractually agree that service at the address of the agent will constitute proper service for the purposes of Rule 6.1.1 of the Civil Procedure Rules. In order to meet the requirements of Rule 6.1.1 an appropriate contractual clause needs to be inserted into the agreement specifying the details of the appointment.
It is also possible to appoint a Process Agent for the purposes of arbitration proceedings in a similar manner.
The role of a process agent<ref>[https://www.lawdebenture.com/our-services/united-kingdom/process-agent/what-is-the-role-of-a-process-agent/ What Is The Role of a Process Agent?]</ref> is a vitally important service for many businesses dealing with suppliers, banks or tenders in the UK. Process agents accept service of notices, proceedings or documents on behalf of their overseas clients in situations where it is not possible for them to be served abroad. A process agent can act in a broad capacity for a company including but not limited to; acting as a process agent for court actions, receiving documents in connection with arbitration proceedings and receiving notices under contracts where an independent party is needed.
A typical example of a process agency arrangement is where an overseas entity raises a loan from a city institution. Often the lending bank will require the appointment of a UK-based process agent<ref>[https://www.lawdebenture.com/our-services/united-kingdom/process-agent/ UK-based Process Agent]</ref> to receive formal notices should the borrower default on the loan.

'''Resource distribution''' refers to the distribution of [[resource (economics)|resources]], including [[Land (economics)|land]], [[water]], [[mineral]]s, [[fuel]] and [[distribution of wealth|wealth in general]] among corresponding geographic entities (states, countries, etc.).
== Unequal resource distribution == {{Main|Economic inequality}}
The most common use of this concept has not been in examining the unequal distribution of resources among nation states. Such unequal distribution of resources was commonly related to land for [[agriculture]], necessary for [[population growth]]. A more recent emphasis has been on differences from the unequal dispersion of [[technological progress]].
== International trade ==
The growth of [[international trade]] is an aspect of [[globalization]] in the later 20th Century (see [[OECD]]), which has affected [[international relations]]. Increased international trade from the removal of [[trade barrier]]s has narrowed income distribution among some nation states. Many wealthier countries export non-land-intensive goods and services in return for agricultural and animal products, as illustrated by Japan.
== See also ==
* [[Free trade]] * [[Human rights]] * [[Logistics]] * [[Transport]]

A [[company (law)|company]] is said to be '''thinly capitalised''' when the level of its debt is much greater than its [[equity capital]], i.e. its [[Gearing (finance)|gearing]], or leverage, is very high. An entity's debt-to-equity funding is sometimes expressed as a ratio. For example, a gearing ratio of 1.5:1 means that for every $2 of equity the entity has $3 of debt.
A high gearing ratio can create problems for: * creditors, which bear the solvency risk of the company, and * revenue authorities, which are concerned about excessive interest claims.
==Credit risk== If the shareholders have introduced only a nominal amount of paid-up [[share capital]], then the company has lower financial reserves with which to meet its obligations. If all or most of the company's capital comes from debt, which (unlike equity) needs to be serviced, and ultimately repaid, it means that the providers of capital are ultimately competing with the company's trade creditors for the same capital resources.
In general, most common law countries tend not to employ thin capitalisation rules in relation to [[Capital requirement|raising and maintenance of capital]]. However, a number of civil law jurisdictions do.
However, in almost all jurisdictions there are certain types of regulated entity which require a certain amount, or a certain proportion, of paid-up share capital to be licensed to trade. The most common examples of this are [[bank]]s and [[insurance company|insurance companies]]. This is because if such companies were to fail and go into [[liquidation]] the economic effect of such failures can lead to a [[domino effect]], which can have catastrophic consequences for other businesses and, ultimately, national economies.
==Tax issues== Even where countries’ corporate laws permit companies to be thinly capitalised, revenue authorities in those countries will often limit the amount that a company can claim as a tax deduction on interest, particularly when it receives loans at non-commercial rates (e.g. from connected parties). However, some countries simply disallow interest deductions above a certain level from all sources when the company is considered to be too highly geared under applicable tax regulations.
Some tax authorities limit the applicability of thin capitalisation rules to corporate groups with foreign entities to avoid “tax leakage” to other jurisdictions. The United States “earnings stripping” rules are an example. Hong Kong protects tax revenue by prohibiting payers from claiming tax deductions for interest paid to foreign entities, thus eliminating the possibility of using thin capitalisation to shift income to a lower-tax jurisdiction.<ref>[http://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/pdf/e_dipn13a.pdf Profits tax: Deductibility of interest expense]. Hong Kong Inland Revenue Department, Departmental Interpretation and Practise Notes #13A. December 2004.</ref>
'''Thin capitalisation rules''' determine how much of the interest paid on corporate debt is deductible for tax purposes. Such rules are of interest to [[Financial Sponsor|private-equity firm]]s, which use significant amounts of debt to finance [[leveraged buyout]]s, and in the context of strategic acquisitions, where the purchaser wishes to push debt into higher taxed countries with significant pre-tax income.<ref>[http://www.altassets.com/casefor/sectors/2004/nz4664.php Article on thin capitalisation rules on AltAssets.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930123139/http://www.altassets.com/casefor/sectors/2004/nz4664.php |date=September 30, 2011 }}</ref>

{{Infobox video game | title = Trade Empires | image = Trade Empires UK box art.png | caption = Retailed box art in the United Kingdom | developer = [[Frog City Software]] | publisher = [[Take-Two Interactive]] (UK)
[[Eidos Interactive]] (US) | series = | engine = | released = {{vgrelease|NA|25 September 2001|EU|11 February 2001}} | genre = [[Business simulation game]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''Trade Empires''' is a PC game developed by [[Frog City Software]] in [[San Francisco]] and published by [[Eidos Interactive]]. During development its working title was '''The Silk Road'''; however, this was changed by Eidos Interactive as they were concerned about the title being too [[highbrow]]. Trade Empires is a pausable real-time strategy game about building a merchant empire. Gamers build vast transport and trade networks that change over thousands of years as new technologies are developed and more modern products are discovered. The rules of the game are simple; the variety comes in through the discovery of new products to trade and new ways to transport those products. ==Gameplay== * Play the first trading and transporting simulation to emphasize the effects of technological change over thousands of years on the relatively simple model of producing and delivering commodities to make more money than the competition. * Start out simple, with one merchant and his donkeys. Gradually build up your merchant empire until you control a vast trading web. * Manipulate the supply and demand economy to dominate the other merchant families. Corner the market. Undercut their prices. * Explore and Exploit: Continually discover new markets and products, from silk in the Far East to steel in industrial Europe. * Adapt your family's trading network to an ever-changing economy or instead face defeat when your competitors purchase advanced technology and deliver superior products. * Span the centuries and the world, in regions from Ancient Sumeria to 19th century Europe. * Build vast transportation networks, using anything from dirt trails to railroads. * Compete against other merchant families who are powered by a clever artificial intelligence that plays by the same rules you do. * Rendered units and buildings on a 3D map. * More than 200 structures and 30 units in 15 different episodes. ==Campaigns== The game features 19 campaign scenarios based on historical trading periods in human history. A step-by-step walkthrough is playable by users on the ''Learn to Play'' mode for the [[Shang Dynasty]] of [[People's Republic of China|China]] (1700-1100 BC). The game imitates the historical period through the supply and demand process of that time. Goods such as [[rice]], [[millet]], [[silk]] cloth and [[Chinese jade|jade idols]] are traded during the campaign. The [[Tang Dynasty|Tang]] & [[Song Dynasty|Song]] Era (AD 615-1280) of China is also depicted, although not as a ''Learn to Play'' option. Other [[Asia]]n trading periods include ''First Civilization'' (2500-2310 BC); based around the regions of the [[Indus Valley]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Zagros Mountains|Zagros]], [[Mesopotamia]] and [[Assyria]]. ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/trade-empires|name=''Trade Empires''}} [[Category:2001 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Eidos Interactive games]] [[Category:Trade simulation games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]]

[[File:Victor Koo.jpg|thumb|Victor Koo]]
'''Victor Koo''' or '''Gu Yongqiang''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|古|永|鏘}}|p=Gǔ Yǒngqiāng}}) served as president [[Sohu.com]] before leaving to co-found video website [[Youku]] in 2006, which merged with [[Tudou]] in 2012,<ref name="Kathrin Hille">{{cite news | last= Hille | first= Kathrin | url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/27d4df96-6c2f-11e1-8c9d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1sG6myrCm | title= Youku and Tudou to merge amid cost rises | publisher= [[ft.com]] | date= March 12, 2012 | accessdate= 16 Apr 2012}}</ref><ref name="DAVID BARBOZA">{{cite news | last= BARBOZA | first= DAVID | url= http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/chinese-video-sites-youku-and-tudou-to-merge/ | title= 2 Video Web Sites in China Plan a Merger | publisher= [[nytimes.com]] | date= 12 March 2012 | accessdate= 16 April 2012}}</ref> creating one of [[internet in the People's Republic of China|China's]] premiere video portals.<ref name="Kazunori Takada">{{cite news | last= Takada | first= Kazunori | url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/12/youku-tudou-idUSL4E8EC3K320120312 | title= Youku to buy Tudou, creating China online video giant | publisher= [[reuters.com]] | date= 12 March 2012 | accessdate= 16 April 2012}}</ref> Prior to the announcementof the merger, Youku was the #11 website in China, and Tudou was #14.<ref name="Russell Flannery">{{cite news | last= Flannery | first= Russell | url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/russellflannery/2012/03/12/land-of-the-large-youku-tudou-merger-latest-in-chinas-web-consolidation/ | title= Land Of The Large: Youku, Tudou Merger Latest In China's Web Consolidation | publisher= [[forbes.com]] | date= 3 December 2012 | accessdate= 16 April 2012}}</ref>
==Education== Koo obtained an [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] from [[Stanford Business School]] and a [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] from the [[University of California at Berkeley]],<ref name="Kerry A. Dolan">{{cite news | last= Dolan | first= Kerry | url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2010/12/08/youku-ipo-mints-a-new-chinese-billionaire-victor-koo/ | title= Youku IPO Mints A New Chinese Billionaire, Victor Koo | publisher= [[forbes.com]] | date= 12 August 2010 | accessdate= 16 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/m/beijing/zhongguancun/2012-01/13/content_14439675.htm|title=Gu Yongqiang|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date=2017-04-26}}</ref> making him a ''[[haigui]]''.
==Net worth== Following the 2010 listing of Youku on the [[New York Stock Exchange]], Koo is a [[List of Chinese by net worth|billionaire]].<ref name="Malcolm Moore">{{cite news | last= Moore | first= Malcolm | url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/china-business/8201764/Youku-founder-Victor-Koo-believes-only-China-can-help-his-company-grow-make-money-and-even-beat-piracy.html | title= Youku founder Victor Koo believes only China can help his company grow, make money and even beat piracy | publisher= [[telegraph.co.uk]] | date= 14 December 2010 | accessdate= 16 April 2012}}</ref>
==Personal life== Koo was born in [[Hong Kong]] in 1966. His father is from [[Guangzhou]] and his mother is from [[Tianjin]]. He has one sister.<ref>{{zh icon}} [http://baike.baidu.com/view/251879.htm 古永锵] 百度百科</ref>

[[File:Zosimaia.jpg|thumb|19th century picture of Zosimaia school.]] The '''Zosimades''' ({{lang-el|Ζωσιμάδες}}) or '''Zosimas brothers''' were 18th-19th century [[Greeks|Greek]] benefactors and merchants.
The Zosimades were six brothers:
*Ioannis Zosimas (1752–1771) *[[:File:Anastasios Zosimas.JPG|Anastasios Zosimas]] (1754–1828) *[[Nikolaos Zosimas]] (1758–1842) *Theodosios Zosimas (1760–1793) *[[Zois Zosimas]] (1764–1828) *Michael Zosimas (1766–1809)
They were born in [[Ioannina]], a city that was under [[Ottoman Greece|Ottoman]] rule and a major center of the [[Greek Enlightenment]] that time. Their father was a local merchant, Panagis Zosimas. At 1875, Nikolaos, Theodosios and Michael started their trading activities in [[Livorno]], [[Italy]], while Ioannis, Anastasios and Zois ran their trade business in [[Nizhyn]] ([[Ukraine]]) and then in [[Moscow]]. Their trade network soon became profitable and they managed to make a fortune.
==Benefaction== After Theodosis' death (1793), he wrote in his testament that they should financially support the education of their home city Ioannina. So they donated astronomical amounts of money for the establishment and function of various schools and public libraries. Another huge donation went for the ''National Library'', of [[Adamantios Korais]], one of the major contributors of the Greek Enlightenment movement. Apart from educational institutions, orphanages were also financed. The Zosimades also subsidized the publication of several books.
At 1820, after Zois' death, they supported the establishment of a new school in their home place, which became known as [[Zosimaia School|Zosimaia]]. This institution would become the center of Greek education the following century in the region of [[Epirus]].
During the following outbreak of the [[Greek War of Independence]] (1821–1830) the remaining Zosimades became active members of the patriotic organization [[Philiki Etaireia]] and supported financially the struggle. Zosimades also completely financed the erection of the Monetary Museum of Athens, donating their personal collection of Ancient Greek and Roman currency, as well as the orphanage in [[Patmos]].
